III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for
the continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A youth witnessed another youth get sexually and physically
assaulted by three other youth. One of the offenders remains in the
home and continues to harass this youth verbally and physically. The
youth remains in his room and isolates himself as a result. Staff are
aware and have not intervened.
Investigation Complainant was contacted via telephone on 6/26/25. There was
no additional information to add about the concern.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face on 06/30/2025 at
Methodist. Youth A reported he and Youth B were initially close
friends; however, their relationship changed when Youth B began
engaging in inappropriate behaviors. Youth A reported Youth B
grabbed his arms daily and attempted to play footsie with him. Youth
A reported these behaviors crossed personal boundaries and made
him feel uncomfortable. He reported he did not feel comfortable
disclosing everything but noted Youth B "kept playing too much" by
touching him. Youth A reported he informed Staff 1 about the
situation but felt he was not taken seriously—possibly because he
was laughing during the conversation, which may have been
misunderstood. He reported while he enjoyed spending time alone in
his room playing video games, he did not consider himself isolated.
Youth A also reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 supervised him and the
other youth in the cottage at all times and reported there was no
opportunity for inappropriate behavior to occur unnoticed. He added
Staff 1 and Staff 2 observed Youth B getting too close to him and
verbally redirected Youth B.
Additionally, Youth A reported Youth C told him about a recent fight
involving Youth B, Youth D, Youth E, and Youth F. Youth A was not
present during the incident but reported concerns that something
similar could happen to him—particularly because Youth B remained
in the cottage immediately following the fight. Youth A reported
Youth B was eventually moved to a different cottage after he
disclosed Youth B’s behaviors to his foster care specialist.
Youth B was interviewed face to face on 6/30/25. Youth B
reported originally being placed at Youth A’s Cottage but recently
moved to another cottage due to a complaint made by his peer,
Youth A. Youth B reported he was relocated because his lack of
boundaries upset Youth A. Youth B denied touching Youth A in a
sexual way. Youth B admitted to making inappropriate jokes toward
Youth A. Youth A declined to disclose the specific jokes Youth B told
him. Youth B also said that Youth A stays in his room most of the
2

time playing video games. Youth B reported feeling safe at the
facility and stated that Staff 1 and Staff 2 are always supervising him
and the other youth.
Youth G was interviewed face to face on 7/30/2025 at Methodist.
Youth G reported speaking to Youth A while at his cottage. Youth G
reported Youth B was trying to date him, which made Youth A feel
uncomfortable. Youth G reported once he told the director, Youth B
was moved. Youth G reported he informed the director, leading to
Youth B’s relocation. Youth G reported supervision at his cottage is
good. Youth G reported phone calls are supervised, and staff are
always monitoring the youth. Youth G reported one staff member can
supervise up to three youth and staff regularly walk by to make
periodic checks. Youth G reported Staff 1 consistently supervises
them at all times. Youth G reported if a youth tries to leave the area,
Staff 1 follows behind and reports it immediately. Youth G reported
while watching TV, Staff 1 sits behind the youth, and even during
bathroom breaks, Staff 1 supervises just outside the bathroom.
Youth G reported feeling safe at the Cottage.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face on 7/30/2025 at Methodist.
Staff 1 reported working with both Youth A and Youth B at their
Cottage. Staff 1 reported often having to redirect Youth B and talk to
him about boundaries after witnessing horseplay between the youth,
but Staff 1 never witnessed Youth B touch Youth A in a sexual
manner. Staff 1 reported the boys played together every day. Staff 1
reported witnessing Youth A telling Youth B to move away and
reported that Youth A expressed irritation with Youth B. However,
Staff 1 reported not seeing Youth B touch Youth A inappropriately.
Staff 1 reported no incident report was made regarding Youth B
acting inappropriately toward Youth A. Staff 1 reported not filing a
report because no sexual behavior was observed between Youth B
and Youth A. However, Staff 1 reported speaking with Youth A’s
therapist and recommended that the therapist address boundaries
with Youth B. Staff 1 reported that Youth A spends a lot of time in his
room playing video games but has never indicated that he stays in
his room due to feeling unsafe.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on 7/1/2025. Staff 2
reported being on shift the day Youth B was moved to another
cottage. Staff 2 reported she and Staff 1 work together to supervise
the youth in Youth A’s Cottage. Staff 2 reported Youth B stayed in
his room and had minimal interaction with Youth A on the day he
was moved. Staff 1 reported observing little interaction between the
youth. Staff 1 reported, she overheard Youth A and another youth
talking. Youth A reported he did not like Youth B trying to come onto
3

him and expressed discomfort, so he reported the issue to his case
manager. Staff 1 reported frequently seeing Youth A and Youth B
horseplay and noted that Youth A also horseplays’ with other youth.
Staff 1 reported instructing the youth to immediately stop the
horseplay and reported having to redirect Youth A on the same day.
Director of Residential Services (DRS) was interviewed face to
face on 7/30/2025 at Methodist. DRS reported both Youth A and
Youth B resided in the same cottage until Youth B was removed and
placed in a new cottage. DRS reported immediate action was
implemented by having Youth B moved after Youth A disclosures.
DRS reported there were no incident reports on file that indicate
there being an issue between Youth A and Youth B prior to this
incident. DRS reported Youth A’s reference to Youth C could not
have occurred because Youth C was discharged from the facility on
5/1/25. DRS also reported no incident reports involving Youth C
related to a fight with Youth B, Youth D, Youth E, or Youth F. DRS
reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 work well with the youth and there were
no concerns regarding conduct.
Staff 3 was interviewed via telephone on 8/18/2025. Staff 3
reported working as Youth A’s case manager at Methodist. Staff 3
reported prior to this incident; there were no other concerns reported
regarding Youth A and Youth B interactions. Staff 3 reported Youth A
did not report his concerns directly to her but was made aware. Staff
3 reported Youth B was immediately removed from the cottage and
replaced to a different cottage.
Foster Care specialist was interviewed via telephone on
8/18/2025. The foster care specialist reported Youth A was moved
out of Methodist on 7/16/25 and is now residing in a community
setting. The specialist stated there were no concerns regarding
Methodist’s supervision of Youth A during his placement there. The
foster care specialist also reported Youth A disclosed similar
concerns about Youth B. However, when asked to describe how
Youth B was touching him, it was determined the contact was not
sexual in nature. Youth A stated Youth B grabbed his arms and
pulled on him, which he did not like. Youth A reported to his foster
care specialist Youth B had written him a note asking to be his
boyfriend. Youth A declined the offer, which he said appeared to
escalate Youth B's behavior. He reported Youth B then made a
comment to him such as, “I will turn you gay,” and proceeded to grab
him by the forearm. Youth A reported no marks were left on his skin
and Youth B let go of his arm when a staff member approached. The
specialist noted Youth A has low cognitive functioning and tends to
report inappropriate touching without always being able to distinguish
4

between general inappropriate contact and sexual contact. In this
case, the touching was not considered sexually inappropriate.
Additionally, the specialist reported Youth A was adamant about not
being housed in the same cottage as Youth B. When the incident
was reported, Wolverine staff immediately separated Youth B from
Youth A to allow for an investigation to take place. Foster care
specialist reported implementing a safety plan with Methodist on
06/25/25.
Support Staff was interviewed via telephone on 8/18/25. Support
Staff reported being assigned to assist Youth A with learning his
rights as a foster youth and had met with Youth A only once. Support
Staff reported Youth A disclosed Youth B had made inappropriate
comments, including saying, “I’ll turn you gay,” which made Youth A
feel uncomfortable. Youth A also reported Youth B grabbed his
forearm, which also made him feel uncomfortable. Support Staff
reported initially having concerns about Youth B remaining in the
same cottage as Youth A but noted Youth B was eventually moved.
Documents Reviewed:
Staff 1 personnel file: There was no disciplinary record and Staff 1
completed CPI refresher training on 3/20/25.
Staff 2 personnel file: Staff 2 received discipline on 07/10/25 for
policy and procedure violation unrelated to this investigation. Staff 2
completed Trauma informed care on 2/27/25, CPI training on
2/14/25.
Young Person Supervision Policy:
The primary function of a residential staff member’s role is to ensure
the safety of all young people, which is only accomplished through
effective and appropriate supervision of the children. Direct
supervision constitutes young people being within the line of vision of
staff and in close proximity, which means in the same room or area.
Supervision ensures the safety of all children, by reducing the risk of
and preventing inappropriate behaviors of young people which is not
conducive to a healthy treatment environment.
The two major methods which staff utilizes to supervise are visual
and audio methods. Staff members are expected to make ongoing
visual assessments of the functioning and behavior of the children
they are responsible for. Staff are also expected to attend to the
verbal communications of individual young people and between
young people
Some of the other procedures include:
5

1. Staff members are expected to know the whereabouts and status
of all young people at all times (clinical, med. appt., visits, activities,
etc.). Whenever young people are being transported staff must
ensure all young people are present and accounted for. When a child
leaves the area without permission and within sight, staff must be
directly observing the young person. Staff cannot be watching a
young person from inside a building if a young person is outside.
2. MCHS schedules staff to maintain a 3:1 ratio during waking hour
and 10:1 during sleeping hours. Staff should strive to maintain this
ratio, though there will be times when staff cannot, such as when a
young person goes AWOL or during a restraint. This does not mean
that staff are out of ratio because there are ample staff scheduled to
respond to any young person issues.
3. During sleeping hours, staff must make hourly direct observation
checks (i.e. visually being able to physically see the young person’s
body) of each young person per hour in the cottages at 15 minute
intermittent intervals. Young people can be observed by looking
through the door window in the cottages. These checks must be
documented from the time
that the young person goes down to his/her room for the night up
until the young person exits their room in the morning in the Midnight
Supervision Form.
4. Staff are expected to be mobile within the milieu, not just sitting in
one spot for an hour or more. This includes walking throughout the
milieu to the exact physical location of all the young people and
maintaining constant awareness of the status of each young person
in care. Staff members are expected to actively engage young
people, by having frequent, ongoing conversations with the young
people, having close proximity to the young people, sitting next to the
young people and interacting with them. Staff should pay extra
attention to them and identifying their strengths, i.e., smile attitude,
experiences, and friendliness.
5. Staff must never leave young people unattended or unsupervised.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance based on staff and youth
interviews. The agency followed its supervision policy. All staff and
youth reported Youth A and Youth B always remained supervised
while at Stoner. Both staff admitted the youth often horseplay
together but never witnessed any sexually inappropriate behavior
between Youth A and Youth B. No incident reports support claims
Youth A’s concerns were disregarded. Staff and Youth A reported
once Youth A informed staff, Youth B was relocated to a new
cottage.
Conclusion Violation not Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
